justification: The Methods section states that "participants completed ... the BIS/BAS personality questionnaire (Carver & White, 1994)", an instrument whose very name reflects the Behavioral Inhibition System (BIS) and Behavioral Activation System (BAS) constructs it is designed to assess.

The paper explains that "we had younger and older adults complete a modified two-stage Markov decision task" in order "to determine if reducing the demands on representing a mental model of the state transitions may lead older adults to engage in greater model-based decision-making," showing the task is used to measure model-based control.

Throughout the introduction the authors contrast model-based and model-free strategies and note that the same modified two-stage Markov task "involves learning associations between choice actions and rewards" typical of model-free behavior, indicating the task also indexes model-free decision-making.

The authors state that "we assume that the P300 component covaries with the degree to which participants update their internal state and value representation on a trial-by-trial basis," linking the P300 to valuation prediction errors.

They note that "the FRN has been suggested to be sensitive to negative prediction errors during reinforcement learning tasks (signed prediction errors; Nieuwenhuis et al., 2002; Walsh & Anderson, 2012)," directly connecting FRN amplitudes to RPEs.
The text reports that "the RewP component may be more related to tracking RPE magnitudes on positive outcomes," indicating RewP is used as an electrophysiological measure of reward prediction error.
